author: By Chris Hamby
title: Federal Government Cuts Ties With Troubled Vaccine Maker
description: Emergent BioSolutions ruined millions of doses of Covid-19 vaccines. Now its $600 million deal is canceled.
content: WASHINGTON — The federal government has canceled its contract with a troubled Covid-19 vaccine manufacturer that ruined millions of doses and had to halt production for months after regulators raised serious quality concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: William Conway, Who Reimagined America’s Zoos, Is Dead at 91
description: He sought to conserve wildlife and encouraged zoos to exhibit animals in their natural habitats. But he lost a battle to rename the Bronx Zoo.
content: William G. Conway, an animal conservationist who redefined (but failed to rename) the Bronx Zoo, and who helped recast America’s urban wildlife parks into crowd-pleasing natural habitats designed to generate support for endangered species worldwide, died on Oct. 21 in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Tariro Mzezewa
title: In Trial Opening, Two Starkly Different Views of Ahmaud Arbery’s Death
description: The prosecutor said Mr. Arbery had come “under attack.” Defense attorneys said their clients were justified in chasing him and trying to detain him.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — The trial of the three white men accused of murdering Ahmaud Arbery opened on Friday with the prosecution arguing that Mr. Arbery, a 25-year-old Black man, had come “under attack,” while defense attorneys said that their clients were justified in suspecting Mr. Arbery of burglary, chasing him in their trucks and trying to detain him until the police arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Pfizer Says Its Antiviral Pill Is Highly Effective in Treating Covid
description: Pfizer’s is the second pill to show effectiveness against Covid-19, and it is the first purpose-built to attack the virus that causes the disease.
content: Pfizer announced on Friday that its pill to treat Covid-19 had been found in a key clinical trial to be highly effective at preventing severe illness among at-risk people who received the drug soon after they exhibited symptoms, making it the second antiviral pill to demonstrate efficacy against Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Julie Green, Artist Who Memorialized Inmates’ Last Suppers, Dies at 60
description: For more than two decades, she rendered death row prisoners’ requests for a last meal on a series of plates, bringing a human face to capital punishment.
content: Six tacos, six glazed doughnuts and a Cherry Coke: That was the last meal of a man executed in Oklahoma in July 1999. Rendered in cobalt blue glaze on a white china plate the next year, it was the first in Julie Green’s decades-long art project, “The Last Supper,” which documented the final meals of death row prisoners around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A Covid hot spot in Italy.
content: The Italian port city of Trieste last month became the epicenter of protests against the government’s new health pass. It is now home to a Covid outbreak linked directly to those protests that threatens to burden intensive care units, with an unvaccinated minority endangering public health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Well’s Guide for Getting Through the Holidays
description: We’ve got guidance for lowering risk and coping with unvaccinated relatives, and a gift guide for better living.
content: Let’s start with the good news. We have the tools we need to lower the risk of Covid when traveling or spending time together indoors. They are:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Michael Rubin’s Big Shot
description: Life isn’t all choppers and parties for the king of sports merch — he’s got plans.
content: Last month, after a three-day stretch in New York, Michael Rubin, was anxious to get back to Philadelphia to attend the home opener of the 76ers, the N.B.A. team of which he is an owner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Three Big Questions Heading Into Free Agency
description: Is Carlos Correa the next $300 million player? Would Freddie Freeman leave Atlanta? Can Toronto keep its bargain-bin finds? We may be waiting a long time to find out.
content: With the completion of the World Series, baseball moved immediately into free agency — sort of. The league’s collective bargaining agreement is set to expire on Dec. 1, and as a result, very little movement is expected as teams and players alike wait to find out how everything is going to shake out. The possibility exists that the league could enact a lockout on Dec. 2, which would halt all activities until a deal is reached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Aaron Rodgers Lashes Out About N.F.L.’s Vaccine Requirements
description: In an interview given by the quarterback as he isolated because of a positive coronavirus test, he said that he was a victim of a “woke mob” and that he had unsuccessfully petitioned the N.F.L. to accept his alternative to being vaccinated.
content: Aaron Rodgers on Friday spoke publicly for the first time since news broke that he was not vaccinated against the coronavirus and had tested positive, lashing out at the news media and saying he was a victim of a “woke mob” and “cancel culture.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: The judge rules on several pretrial motions in favor of the prosecution.
description: On Thursday, Judge Timothy Walmsley heard several legal motions on what details of the Ahmaud Arbery case the jury will be allowed to hear.
content: Judge Timothy R. Walmsley, who is presiding over the Ahmaud Arbery murder trial, ruled on a number of legal motions ahead of opening statements, including allowing into evidence video images from the body camera of a responding police officer who hovered over Mr. Arbery after he was shot.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our reporters are breaking down the jobs numbers.
description: The New York Times’s economics reporters, including Ben Casselman, Neil Irwin, Jeanna Smialek and Talmon Smith, are pulling out the most interesting and important parts of Friday’s jobs report.
content: The New York Times’s economics reporters, including Ben Casselman, Neil Irwin, Jeanna Smialek and Talmon Smith, are pulling out the most interesting and important parts of Friday’s jobs report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: State Dept. Report on Missing Gifts Finds Poor Oversight
description: The gift vault was “in a state of disarray,” and tens of thousands of dollars of items remain unaccounted for, including a $5,800 bottle of whiskey.
content: The State Department’s inspector general has found in a new report that tens of thousands of dollars in gifts purchased with government funds during the Trump administration to give to foreign leaders and others given to senior officials are unaccounted for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: ‘We serve a God who is not asleep’: Clergy members urge unity for Ahmaud Arbery’s family.
description: Ministers asked Brunswick, Ga., to remain peaceful despite unhappiness that a nearly all-white jury had been seated in the trial of the white men accused of killing Ahmaud Arbery, a Black man.
content: A group of clergy members gathered outside the Glynn County Superior Court in Brunswick, Ga., on Friday morning, urging the community to remain peaceful and united despite their unhappiness that a nearly all-white jury had been seated in the trial of the white men accused of killing Ahmaud Arbery, a Black man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: New York Becomes Marathon City Once Again
description: The marathon’s comeback from a pandemic that brought the city to a standstill will make it especially meaningful.
content: It’s Friday. We’ll look at the New York City Marathon, which will celebrate its 50th running this weekend with an expected 30,000 people on the starting line. We’ll also look at the continuing fallout from Election Day in New York and New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Febos
title: Memoirs of Womanhood by Emily Ratajkowski, Toufah Jallow and N. West Moss
description: Three autobiographical debuts reveal the pain and power of the female condition.
content: MY BODY EssaysBy Emily Ratajkowski 237 pp. Metropolitan Books. $26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Turning Back the Clock
description: After a busy week, we offer six stories that caught our eyes.
content: After a busy week of news — elections, Supreme Court arguments, the World Series and, alas, a never-ending pandemic — today’s newsletter is going to try something different. My colleagues and I will tell you about six stories that we can’t stop thinking about and that you may have missed this week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Delayed 50th Marathon Is Milestone of the City’s Resilience
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 5, 2021.
content: “Being able to run the marathon and see all these other people who are also very cognizant that New York is still alive and well — I feel like that’s going to be really powerful.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: ‘Justice for my daughter’: Parents issue a plea on air pollution.
description: A letter to world leaders gathered at the U.N. climate conference in Glasgow was signed by nearly 500 parent groups from 44 countries.
content: GLASGOW — A delegation of mothers from Brazil, Britain, India, Nigeria, Poland and South Africa, including one whose daughter last year became the first person in Britain to have air pollution officially listed as her cause of death, arrived at the COP26 climate summit this week with a message to leaders: End the financing of fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: John Kerry lauds progress at the climate summit but warns, ‘Job not done.’
description: Mr. Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, acknowledged that many of the promises being put forward in Glasgow were only that — promises.
content: As the United Nations climate summit neared its halfway mark, the Biden administration on Friday tried to strike a balance between lauding the new promises that countries have made this week to curb emissions and warning that they still need to do far more to avert the worst impacts of global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Barliant
title: An Illustrated History of Bad Art Friends
description: Is there a line between being inspired by others’ lives and stealing from them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Zazie Beetz and Regina King on Their Big Battle in ‘The Harder They Fall’
description: In the Netflix western, the two actresses, playing members of rival cowboy gangs, engage in an epic fight. Here, they break down the scene.
content: “Trudy’s mine,” hisses Stagecoach Mary Fields (played by Zazie Beetz), her eyes blazing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Do You Think It Is Time to Get Rid of Daylight Saving Time?
description: Why are we still changing our clocks twice a year? Is it worth it?
content: Daylight Saving begins on Sunday, Nov. 7. It’s the time of year when we turn our clocks back one hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Hunter Biden: Emotionally Honest, Generically Smooth
description: The president’s son has turned to art as a career. “The Journey Home” is his first solo exhibition.
content: Hunter Biden is an emerging artist from Wilmington, Del. He is now, like no shortage of emerging artists, based in Los Angeles, but unlike them he is making his debut in New York at ample scale, with a solo exhibition at the Georges Bergès Gallery in SoHo. The show is titled “The Journey Home,” and it is not small: more than two dozen paintings, works on paper and overpainted photographs, installed across two floors, melodramatically spotlit. Circumstances require that the show is currently open only by appointment. When I saw it this past weekend, I was greeted by a security guard charged to protect the staff from death threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: In her opening statement, the lead prosecutor says Ahmaud Arbery was ‘under attack.’
description: The prosecution detailed how three defendants chased Mr. Arbery in two pickup trucks and the confrontation that ended with his death.
content: The lead prosecutor in the trial of the three white men accused of murdering Ahmaud Arbery said in her opening statement on Friday that Mr. Arbery was plainly “under attack” by the defendants when they chased him in trucks through their neighborhood — a chase that ended with one of the defendants, Travis McMichael, fatally shooting Mr. Arbery with his pump-action shotgun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Lara Jakes
title: Eight Groups Join Tigray Rebels Vowing to Oust Ethiopia’s Leader
description: The government calls the new coalition, announced in Washington, a “publicity stunt,” as intermediaries try to negotiate a peaceful solution to a year of conflict.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — For a year now, fighters from Ethiopia’s northern region of Tigray have faced off against Ethiopia’s army largely alone, repulsing their attacks, capturing towns and this week, advancing on the capital, Addis Ababa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Aaron Feuerstein, Mill Owner Who Refused to Leave, Dies at 95
description: After a fire devastated his Massachusetts factory in 1995, he kept paying his employees and spent hundreds of millions to rebuild.
content: Aaron Feuerstein, a Massachusetts industrialist who became a national hero in 1995 when he refused to lay off workers at his textile plant after a catastrophic fire, then spent hundreds of millions of dollars to rebuild it, died on Thursday at a hospital in Boston. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Highest Vaccination Rate in California
description: Once an anti-vaccine stronghold, Marin County has become an unlikely champion of Covid-19 shots. But will it last?
content: The pocket of California that has emerged as a leader in Covid-19 vaccinations may come as a surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Felice Neals
title: The Curious Tale of Mr. Kale
description: He was everything I expected and wanted. So why hasn’t he returned to Whole Foods?
content: I met Mr. Kale on the checkout line at Whole Foods in TriBeCa more than two years ago. It was in the cards — sort of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Don’t Throw Away That Ancient Pink Toilet. Someone Out There Wants It.
description: Retro-minded homeowners are driving across the country and paying thousands of dollars to restore or recreate a vintage bathroom or kitchen.
content: Many people might look at a vintage lilac-and-green bathroom and see a space begging to be gutted. But those people are not Emilie Carver, a Cleveland lawyer who hopped on a plane last May and flew to Boston to retrieve 600 tiles from a bathroom that was being renovated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Persistent shortages are stunting German economic growth.
description: The order books in Europe’s largest economy are full, but a lack of parts and raw materials means companies are struggling to fill them.
content: Persistent shortages are dragging down the German economy, Europe’s largest, as companies struggle to fill orders because the necessary parts or raw materials are not arriving from abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt, William K. Rashbaum, Precious Fondren and Adam Goldman
title: People Tied to Project Veritas Scrutinized in Theft of Diary From Biden’s Daughter
description: The F.B.I. carried out search warrants in New York as part of a Justice Department investigation into how pages from Ashley Biden’s journal came to be published by a right wing website.
content: The Justice Department searched two locations associated with the conservative group Project Veritas as part of an investigation into how a diary stolen from President Biden’s daughter, Ashley, came to be publicly disclosed a week and a half before the 2020 presidential election, according to people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: JoAnna Cameron, an Early Female Superhero on TV, Is Dead at 73
description: In addition to achieving Saturday morning fame as Isis, she was said to have appeared in more national television commercials than anyone in advertising history.
content: JoAnna Cameron, who in the 1970s portrayed Isis, the first female character on television with superpowers, and appeared in more national network television commercials than anyone else, died on Oct. 15 in Oahu, Hawaii. She was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Huma Abedin Talks About ‘Both/And’
description: Abedin discusses her new memoir, and Gary Shteyngart talks about his latest novel, “Our Country Friends.”
content: In her new memoir, “Both/And: A Life in Many Worlds,” Huma Abedin writes about her Muslim faith, her years working alongside Hillary Clinton and, of course, her relationship with her estranged husband, the former Democratic Representative Anthony Weiner. On this week’s podcast, Abedin says that writing the book was “the most therapeutic thing I could have possibly done,” and that writing about her marriage and its time in the tabloids gave her perspective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
title: Young Activists Want Action as Protesters Rally at COP26
description: For many, the climate conference has inspired mixed emotions: concern that their voices were not really being listened to, but also hope that their presence would help drive change.
content: GLASGOW — Thousands of climate activists from across the world have descended this week on the Scottish city of Glasgow, demanding that nations gathering for a global climate conference produce real, meaningful change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri and Ashley Wong
title: How to Track Runners in the New York City Marathon
description: Spectators can track runners online and on an app in real time on race day.
content: If you’re cheering for runners in the New York City Marathon this weekend, you can track them in real time on the TCS New York City Marathon app, the official race app. All runners will be tracked via a chip in their marathon bibs, and will show up on the app’s marathon map as blue icons so you can follow their progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zena Agha
title: Israel Moves to Silence the Stalwarts of Palestinian Civil Society
description: These human rights activists are not terrorists.
content: On Oct. 19, the Israeli Ministry of Defense singled out six of the most prominent Palestinian human rights and civil society organizations, using secret, and thus far insufficient, evidence to accuse them of being “terrorist” organizations with links to a militant group. Just days later, Israel approved the construction of more than 3,000 new settlement units in the occupied West Bank and announced plans to double the Jewish-Israeli population in the Jordan Valley by 2026.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: ‘There was blood all over’: A police officer describes the scene of Ahmaud Arbery’s death.
description: When William Duggan, a Glynn County police officer, arrived on the scene of the shooting, what he observed was gruesome.
content: When William Duggan, a Glynn County police officer, arrived on the scene of Ahmaud Arbery’s shooting, what he observed was gruesome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Snail Mail Turns a Bleeding Heart Into a Spectacular Album
description: On her second LP, “Valentine,” the singer and guitarist Lindsey Jordan delivers direct lyrics and wrenching melodies in the service of vivid emotional truths.
content: Lindsey Jordan is far from the first person to have her heart broken, but “Valentine,” her remarkable second album as Snail Mail, is alive with such crackling and revelatory emotion that for about 32 minutes it allows you to suspend disbelief and imagine — well, what if she is?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Finding Love on the Overnight Shift
description: Averi Harper and Kenneth Robinson met on a San Francisco train six years ago. As luck would have it, they both had “unconventional schedules.”
content: Averi Harper and Kenneth Robinson, who met on a San Francisco train in September 2015, knew they might be destined for a future together when they realized their schedules had something in common: neither worked on Mondays or Tuesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Wages are rising, but can they keep up with inflation?
description: In the tug of war between wage growth and rising prices, it is not yet clear who is winning. It could matter for the Federal Reserve.
content: American workers are taking home bigger paychecks as employers pay up to attract and retain employees. But those same people are shelling out more for furniture, food and many other goods and services these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: ‘I Don’t Want to Die for It’: School Board Members Face Rising Threats
description: Across the country, parents have threatened board members and vandalized their homes. One board member scans his driveway before walking to his car.
content: It was only days after Sami Al-Abdrabbuh was re-elected to the school board in Corvallis, Ore., that the text messages arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Breaking Down the Biden Vaccine Mandate
description: New details have clarified the forthcoming requirements — and prompted questions and concerns.
content: The Biden administration yesterday set Jan. 4 as the deadline for large companies to mandate coronavirus vaccinations or start weekly testing for their workers. The rule is expected to cover 84 million workers, roughly 31 million of whom are unvaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Kristen Stewart’s Princess Diaries
description: The actress is drawing Oscar talk for her portrayal of Princess Diana in “Spencer,” a role that required the sort of performance she had never given before.
content: Kristen Stewart has sometimes been accused of just playing variations on herself, as if that isn’t half the reason we’re drawn to movie stars. In “Twilight” (2008), she brought a specific and sullen appeal to a heroine conceived as a blank slate for female readers; later, in “Personal Shopper” (2017), when Stewart traded her polo shirts for a rich client’s shimmering dress, you could see both the star and the character regarding her new look in the mirror: Is this me? Could I make it me?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times and Jeré Longman
title: 26.2 at 50
description: The New York City Marathon’s 50th running is on Sunday. This is the story of one race, five boroughs, dozens of champions and over a million hopeful runners.
content: The New York City Marathon is one of the world’s largest road races and most democratic. Olympic medalists and world champions run the same 26.2 miles as weekend warriors. There have been 1,283,005 total finishers over 49 runnings, and thousands of photographs captured by scores of photographers for The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: Here’s what to watch for in the House on Friday.
description: Democratic leaders were aiming to pass the $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill, but they postponed a vote on the $1.85 trillion social safety net and climate change measure.
content: Democratic leaders in the House, aiming to break through an intraparty stalemate, are trying to hold key votes on President Biden’s agenda on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Grace Ashford and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Cuomo Sex-Crime Charge May Be ‘Defective,’ D.A. Says
description: The Albany County district attorney said that the local sheriff “unilaterally and inexplicably” filed a criminal complaint without his involvement.
content: The sex-crime case against former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was thrown into doubt on Friday after the Albany County, N.Y., district attorney delivered an extraordinary public denunciation of the local sheriff, saying the criminal complaint the sheriff filed last week was “potentially defective.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: When Art and Music Collide
description: While Brandon George was performing flute music to celebrate a new exhibit at the Met, he couldn’t help but notice the exhibit’s curator, Adam Eaker.
content: Adam Samuel Eaker was looking forward to an evening of music the night he met Brandon Patrick George in March 2019. Falling for the musician, though, was not meant to be part of the program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: The ‘Crush’ That Turned Into Something Much More
description: Ernest Owens and Barry Johnson met in 2013 at a Black fraternity party at the University of Pennsylvania, where both were students.
content: Ernest Owens spotted Barry Johnson at a Black fraternity party in 2013, during Mr. Johnson’s first week of orientation for new students at the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Owens, then beginning his senior year, was quick to introduce himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Chelsea Daniel, Eric Krupke, Mike Benoist, Lisa Tobin and Chris Wood
title: The Trial of Kyle Rittenhouse
description: Prosecutors describe the teenager who shot and killed two people at protests in Kenosha, Wis., as an illegally armed out-of-towner. His team say he was defending himself.
content: This episode contains strong language and scenes of violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in November
description: Our picks for November, including ‘tick, tick … BOOM!’, ‘The Great’ Season 2, and ‘Passing’
content: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: It’s Sign-Up Time for Federal Health Insurance
description: Consumers are likely to see more plan options and lower premiums for next year. “This is a whole new ballgame,” one health expert said.
content: The annual open enrollment for Affordable Care Act health insurance plans is underway, and consumers not only have more time to sign up, they are also likely to see more plan options and lower premiums for next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: To Build the Metaverse, Meta First Wants to Build Stores
description: The social networking company has discussed opening physical stores to showcase its virtual reality and augmented reality devices.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — One of Mark Zuckerberg’s first steps toward building the metaverse may be physical instead of virtual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Besha Rodell
title: Laughs No More? Australians Are Reassessing a Beloved Cartoonist.
description: I used to think Michael Leunig’s drawings embodied the soul of our nation. Now, I’m not so sure.
content: Among my family’s most prized possessions is a small framed drawing of two faeries holding hands, flying through the night sky. It is an original by the Australian cartoonist Michael Leunig. He gave it to my mother after it accompanied an article she wrote in The Age newspaper in the early 1980s, about my 5-year-old claim that I was the Queen of the Faeries. Until recently, this was a simple treasure: a drawing of me and my mother imagined by one of Australia’s most beloved artists. My feelings about it recently have become a bit more complicated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Making Time to Connect on a Wednesday
description: Whitney Montgomery at first refused Lennie Breland’s invitation for a midweek first date. But he persisted.
content: Getting out of work early enough for a midweek date was almost impossible for Whitney Montgomery when she met Lennie Breland on the dating app Black People Meet in October 2013. So when Mr. Breland asked her for a first date on a Wednesday, she suggested a different day. But he was pretty insistent about Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walt Bogdanich and Michael Forsythe
title: Congress Is Investigating McKinsey Over Its Role in the Opioid Crisis
description: A House committee has requested documents related to the firm’s advice to drug makers and potential conflicts of interest with the F.D.A.
content: In a new assault on the global consulting giant McKinsey & Company, Congress on Friday started an investigation into the firm’s role in the opioid crisis, sending a letter demanding records related to its “business practices, conflicts of interest and management standards.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Marian Anderson: A Voice of Authenticity and Justice
description: A new box set explores the singer whose Lincoln Memorial concert was a 20th-century civil rights milestone.
content: The night before Marian Anderson’s 1939 concert on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, she called Sol Hurok, her manager, to ask if she really had to go through with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Audra D. S. Burch and Patricia Mazzei
title: Trapped in a Pandemic Funk: Millions of Americans Can’t Shake a Gloomy Outlook
description: Despite signals that the economy is improving and the virus is waning, many Americans said they were frustrated by polarized politics and a sense of stagnancy.
content: A year ago, Michael Macey, a barber who lives in the suburbs outside Atlanta, was thrilled to help propel President Biden to victory, hopeful that Democrats would move swiftly to tackle policing laws and other big issues. But then he watched his hopes for sweeping changes wither in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: In a World That Exploits Women, Emily Ratajkowski Exploits Herself. Is That Progress?
description: The essays in Ratajkowski’s book “My Body” explore the troubled and troubling ambiguities where capitalism meets objectification.
content: The figure of the modeling agent must be up there with the personal injury lawyer and the tobacco lobbyist as far as stock villain professions go. Has an honorable and kindly modeling agent ever been committed to print, film, television or stage? Are those very words doomed to suggest a leering cartoon rubbing his hands together and making “ah-ooga” noises as an underpaid model toils to funnel money into his cartoon bank account?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: In Fate of Oil Field, Climate Activists and Energy Executives See Future
description: What is Cambo? It’s a proposed oil field deep underwater off Scotland that has become an intense focus of environmentalists and the energy industry.
content: LONDON — A once-unremarkable patch of ocean floor in deep waters northwest of Scotland’s Shetland Islands has become a crucial test case for the British government, environmental groups and the oil industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Dudding
title: Infrastructure, Cuomo, N.Y.C. Marathon: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Kamaru Usman Wants U.F.C. Glory but to Still Live Normally
description: Content to hang out with his daughter mostly unbothered, Usman, the U.F.C. welterweight champion, does not aspire for the fame of Conor McGregor. But he does have his eye on something big.
content: Kamaru Usman, one of the fiercest men on the planet, is content with the level of fame he has achieved in this bloody sport of mixed martial arts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Remains in Colorado Are Believed to Be West German Hiker Missing Since 1983
description: Rudi Moder, who was described as an experienced winter mountaineer, disappeared nearly 40 years ago during a skiing trip in Rocky Mountain National Park.
content: Human remains found in Rocky Mountain National Park in Colorado are believed to be those of a hiker who disappeared nearly 40 years ago during a ski trip, officials at the park said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Ashley Southall
title: What Happens if the Supreme Court Strikes Down New York’s Gun Law?
description: Legal experts said New York and several other states may have to rewrite laws, and officials expressed concern about the ramifications for public safety.
content: New York State has one of the most restrictive gun laws in the country, sharply limiting people’s ability to carry weapons outside their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How the New York City Marathon’s Race Director Spends His Sundays
description: Although Ted Metellus runs only on weekdays, he is committed to making it happen this weekend for about 30,000 others.
content: This year represents the 50th “running” anniversary of the New York City Marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Their Love for Fun Inspired a Love for Each Other
description: Douglas Atkins and Charles Huck discovered that the only thing better than enjoying life is enjoying it as a couple.
content: Douglas Atkins and Charles Huck say their love for each other comes from finding the fun in everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Labor force participation is static, a conundrum for the Fed.
description: Federal Reserve officials want to know where things stand in the job market’s recovery. It’s tricky to guess that, with so many workers on the sidelines.
content: Millions of employees remain on the job market’s sidelines and are only slowly trickling back — posing a serious challenge for the Federal Reserve as its policymakers try to assess how far the United States economy remains from their full employment goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: University of Florida Reverses Course to Allow Professors to Testify Against State
description: Facing a storm of protest, the university said three professors could testify as expert witnesses in a voting-rights lawsuit against the state.
content: Acceding to a storm of protest, the University of Florida abandoned efforts on Friday to keep three political science professors from testifying in a voting-rights lawsuit against the administration of Gov. Ron DeSantis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Ex-Macron Aide Convicted of Assault and Posing as a Police Officer
description: The aide, Alexandre Benalla, who was fired in 2018 after videos emerged of him beating a man at a labor protest, was sentenced to serve a year of house arrest with electronic monitoring.
content: PARIS — A former security aide to President Emmanuel Macron of France was found guilty on Friday of assaulting protesters and posing as a police officer at a labor demonstration in 2018, in a case that caused the administration’s first major scandal and led to intense criticism of Mr. Macron’s governing style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Tomb of the Unknowns Welcomes the Public for First Time in 73 Years
description: Since 1948, guards have kept tourists and other visitors away from the memorial at Arlington National Cemetery. For two days this month, they will be allowed to get close and place flowers at the tomb.
content: In 1921, a sergeant walked into a small, dark chapel in Châlons-sur-Marne in eastern France, not far from where French and English troops had pushed back against advancing Germans a few years before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel: ‘Aaron Is a Karen’
description: As Covid sidelined the Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers, Kimmel and other hosts scorned him for implying that he’d been vaccinated.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: laissez-faire
description: This word has appeared in 64 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: ‘Love Hard’ Review: Seeking Connection, Not Perfection
description: When a perennially single journalist travels across the country to meet her dream guy, she finds she’s been catfished.
content: “Love Hard,” directed by Hernán Jiménez, centers on Natalie (Nina Dobrev), a Los Angeles journalist who chronicles her unlucky dating encounters for a digital publication. When she matches with her dream guy on the East Coast, Tag (Darren Barnet), she decides on a whim to surprise him for the holidays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: A Body Donated to Science Was Dissected for a Paying Audience
description: The widow of David Saunders, 98, said she did not know the body of her husband, who died of Covid-19, would be taken apart at an Oregon hotel where audience members paid up to $500 to attend.
content: The blurred video showed a cadaver on a table in a hotel ballroom. A man stood over the body, addressing an audience that had paid to watch the dissection of a corpse. Some people snapped on gloves and hovered, peering and touching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Bryan
title: Remaking Diana: Six Faces of a Princess to Stream Online
description: The film “Spencer” is the latest in a long line of TV and movie depictions of Diana. Here’s a selection.
content: LONDON — Nearly 25 years after her death, Diana, Princess of Wales, remains a fixture in British culture and on screens both sides of the pond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Vibing on Art and Artists’ Books
description: Gil Gentile asked Hannah Mandel on a first date to a conceptual art exhibit at the Jewish Museum. A year later they created an artist’s book as a nod to it.
content: Gil Moshe Gentile got it just right in June 2013 when he asked Hannah Marie Mandel to meet him at “Jack Goldstein X 10,000,” a conceptual art exhibit at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Fuller
title: What to Know About ‘Eternals’
description: Who are they? How long have they been here? Where do they fit in the Marvel Cinematic Universe? We have answers.
content: “Eternals,” the latest addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe, is a two-and-a-half-hour epic that introduces nearly a dozen new characters, hops back and forth through time over thousands of years, and begins with an opening text crawl that reveals a previously unknown origin of the human species. Even the most ardent MCU fan may be perplexed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Makiko Inoue
title: Japan will shorten quarantine for business travelers to 3 days.
description: The easing of rules comes as cases decline significantly. The country has virtually closed its borders since the start of the pandemic.
content: Japanese officials said on Friday that they would reduce the length of quarantine for vaccinated business travelers from 10 days to three, reflecting the incredible turnaround in the country’s control over the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel and Flávia Milhorance
title: Marília Mendonça, Brazilian Pop Singer, Dies in Plane Crash at 26
description: Ms. Mendonça, who was a social media sensation with millions of followers, was iconic in a type of Brazilian country music called sertanejo.
content: Marília Mendonça, a popular Brazilian pop singer who was known as “The Queen of Suffering” for her soulful, angst-filled ballads, was killed on Friday in a small plane crash in the southeastern state of Minas Gerais in Brazil. She was 26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: ‘It Was Like My Pinterest Board Come to Life’
description: After Zachary Chan surprised Ashley Mungiguerra with a ring on a trip to Amsterdam, the two were married in a “secret garden.”
content: Only a few months after Ashley Mungiguerra and Zachary Chan began dating, an ocean would force them to live apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing directors reach a settlement in a shareholder lawsuit over the 737 Max crashes.
description: The $237.5 million accord is subject to court approval. The plaintiffs said board members had neglected their oversight duties.
content: A group of current and former Boeing directors has agreed to settle a shareholder lawsuit over a pair of fatal crashes that led to the global grounding of the company’s 737 Max jetliner for nearly two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: N.Y.C. Rats: They’re in the Park, on Your Block and Even at Your Table
description: Reported rat sightings, health inspections finding evidence of rat activity and cases of a disease spread via rat urine are all up amid the pandemic.
content: Brittany Brown and her friends were finishing an outdoor dinner in Chelsea recently when, from the corner of her eye, she thought she saw something move near the edge of their table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Job Gains Offer a Brighter Picture of the U.S. Economy
description: Employers added 531,000 jobs in October, a big improvement from the previous month and a sign of optimism as the latest coronavirus surge eases.
content: The American economy is showing renewed signs of life, with employers hiring workers in greater numbers than they have in months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: As Turkey Chafes at Erdogan, He Gets Spikier Abroad
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan canceled an appearance at the global climate talks over a perceived slight, part of a pattern of creating international dramas to bolster his domestic standing.
content: ISTANBUL — The global climate summit in Glasgow was supposed to be a big moment for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey. He was expected to use the chance to show off a new embrace of climate issues, and there are few things he likes more than mingling on the international stage beside other world leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Rights Groups Urge Singapore Not to Execute Man With Mental Disability
description: The man, a Malaysian with an I.Q. of 69, was caught trying to smuggle an ounce and a half of heroin in 2009. Some are calling his planned hanging a human rights violation.
content: Human rights groups are urging Singapore to halt an execution next week of a Malaysian man convicted of smuggling heroin into the city-state, arguing that he should be exempt under international law because he has an intellectual disability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a gangster shoot-em-up, a post-apocalyptic zombie/cannibal thriller, a World War II film and more.
content: For action fans seeking out new movies on streaming, there are plenty of car chases, explosions and fist fights to sift through. We help by providing some streaming highlights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: When Bad News About the Climate Is Good for Green Stocks
description: Markets respond when coverage of global warming spikes, new research suggests. But investors could become inured to the bleak state of climate change.
content: It’s not yet clear how effective the United Nations conference underway in Glasgow will be in mitigating the most pernicious effects of global warming. But one outcome is already evident: The number of news articles about climate change is surging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenée Desmond-Harris
title: Should I Try to Save a Child From Her Adoptive Mom’s Bad Race Politics?
description: There’s one big thing to remember before your kids hang out.
content: I live in Alabama where it has become quite common for white families to adopt Black children. I feel like many of them believe that this action absolves them of any accusation of racism. Personally (I’m Black) I disagree and believe they have an obligation to actively engage in dismantling racist systems and practices on behalf of their child, rather than merely assimilating the child into their families and social circles, which inevitably reflect these same racist systems and inequitable outcomes. The issue is that one mom whom I know through my community activities has pushed for friendships between her children — one of her girls in particular — and my 9-year-old daughter. But from what I’ve seen on social media she is a Trump supporter, has anti-immigrant views and has an “all lives matter” approach to police violence. I would normally not leave my daughter in the care of adults with these values or become “mom friends” with them. But do I have an obligation to get closer to the family for the child’s sake?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Get Your Kill Room Ready. Dexter Is Back.
description: Eight years after the lovable serial killer went into bearded self-exile, he returns for “Dexter: New Blood.” Here’s a refresher on where things left off.
content: “Dexter” ended in 2013, with its protagonist self-exiled to the frozen North and most major characters dead. But you can’t keep a high-functioning psychopath down. “Dexter: New Blood,” which premieres on Showtime on Nov. 7, finds Michael C. Hall’s Dexter Morgan working at a fish and game shop under an assumed name. His side hustles including bladesmithing, goat farming and maybe some vengeance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By André Wheeler
title: Singing the Praises of R.B.G. Style
description: Bibhu Mohapatra and the Washington National Opera pay homage to the Supreme Court justice.
content: The legacy of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg has inspired all sorts of cultural paeons since her death in September 2020. They have included an exhibition of the Justice’s mementos at the New-York Historical Society, an upcoming children’s picture book, and an off-Broadway play written by Dianne Nora. But the latest tribute, a new work from the Washington National Opera, may be the most apropos yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Can I Dress Fashionably Without Irritating My Skin?
description: A reader seeks advice on how to feel stylish while still sticking to safe fabrics.
content: People with disabilities of every kind have long been fashion’s biggest blind spot — and, as far as I am concerned, missed opportunity. Though the industry has been getting notably better about acknowledging and trying to address many of its own failings, including a history of racism, sizeism and ageism, it still falls short when it comes to disabilities. Even if last season there were a few models in wheelchairs on select runways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: At Hunter Biden’s Art Show, Line, Color and Questions
description: Paintings by the president’s son are drawing visitors to a gallery in SoHo, and also criticism from those who worry that purchasers might hope to be buying not just art, but access.
content: Weeks before Hunter Biden’s art show — “The Journey Home” — opened at a New York gallery, marking the splashy debut of a newcomer with a famous name to the commercial art world, the White House insisted it had safeguards to ensure that no one who buys a painting will be able to use the acquisition to influence his father’s administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Tariro Mzezewa
title: Defense lawyers portray the fatal shooting of Ahmaud Arbery as self-defense.
description: The lawyers represent Travis McMichael, who fatally shot Mr. Arbery, and his father. The lawyer for the third defendant deferred his opening statement until later in the trial.
content: In an opening statement on Friday, the lawyer for Travis McMichael, the man who shot and killed Ahmaud Arbery, painted his client as a man who felt a “duty” to protect his neighborhood, and who had reason to believe that Mr. Arbery had committed a burglary — giving him the right, under Georgia law, to carry out a citizen’s arrest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Artifacts Revealed by Climate Change and the Growing Ranks of American Billionaires: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: Landmarks Aren’t Always Forever
description: Here are a few historic structures that were demolished and one that was spared after being declared a landmark at the 11th hour.
content: On a triangular site at Greenwich Avenue, Seventh Avenue and West 12th Street, a grand movie palace was built in 1921, then sold and rebranded as Loew’s Sheridan Theatre in 1926. Attendance waned by the 1960s and it was demolished by its new owner, St. Vincent’s Hospital, in the summer of 1969.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Energy Department Aims to Slash Cost of Removing Carbon From the Air
description: Scientists say carbon removal may be needed to avert the worst effects of climate change. But it still needs to be much cheaper and more reliable.
content: GLASGOW — The U.S. Department of Energy on Friday unveiled its biggest effort yet to drastically reduce the cost of technologies that suck carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere, in a recognition that current strategies to lower greenhouse gases may not be enough to avert the worst effects of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Review: Michael Tilson Thomas, a Podium Hero, Returns
description: The eminent conductor appeared with the New York Philharmonic, his first public performance since brain surgery this summer.
content: In early August, the conductor Michael Tilson Thomas announced that, following surgery to remove a brain tumor, he was withdrawing from his upcoming performances to receive treatment. “I look forward,” he said, “to seeing everyone again in November.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Some Sept. 11 Trial Secrets May Not Be Secrets Anymore
description: Prosecutors agreed to compare hundreds if not thousands of pages of classified documents in the case against 9/11 defendants with material released under the Freedom of Information Act.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Prosecutors volunteered on Friday to review hundreds, perhaps thousands, of pages of classified C.I.A. documents in the Sept. 11 case to determine if some material provided to defense lawyers was too heavily redacted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Two Octogenarians Commit to ‘Living Apart Together’
description: Harry Mirra had no interest in remarrying after the death of his wife until Ginny Valonis, herself a widow, opened his mind to a union on their terms.
content: Harry Mirra made it clear from the start that he didn’t want to marry Ginny Valonis. Back then, though, she was too in love to care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: Tucked Inside a Gilded Age Landmark … a Tropical Bar?
description: The team behind Gage & Tollner is opening Sunken Harbor Club, a pocket bar above the Brooklyn restaurant.
content: How do you follow up a trick like Gage & Tollner? At that Brooklyn chophouse, three partners brought a famous-but-closed restaurant out of dormancy and then pulled it through a yearlong Covid delay to become one of the critical and popular dining successes of 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gal Beckerman
title: What Does War Feel Like to a Child?
description: “How War Changed Rondo,” a picture book by the Ukrainian artists Romana Romanyshyn and Andriy Lesiv, captures the unrelenting destructiveness of wartime as a young person experiences it.
content: HOW WAR CHANGED RONDOBy Romana Romanyshyn and Andriy LesivTranslated by Oksana Lushchevska
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Manitoba Names a New Premier, but a Rival Asks a Court to Quash the Action
description: The litigation highlights the often messy process that Canadian political parties use to select their leaders.
content: Manitoba seems to have a surplus of premiers at the moment. On Tuesday, Heather Stefanson was sworn in as the province’s 24th premier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The activist Vanessa Nakate offers an optimistic vision: ‘We won’t have to fight’ for resources.
description: The 24-year-old from Uganda has emerged as a leading voice of young people agitating for climate action.
content: Vanessa Nakate, a 24-year-old Ugandan activist, used her address to a crowd of protesters in Glasgow on Friday to emphasize the immediate impacts of climate change facing her country and continent, and to draw a picture of a fairer future, arguing that the world could emerge from the climate crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Citing the Pain of a Demanding Job, Buster Posey Retires at 34
description: Posey, the Giants’ catcher and three-time World Series champion, said going out on his own terms was a factor in his decision.
content: Moments after Buster Posey, the star catcher who guided the San Francisco Giants through the team’s greatest era with three World Series titles, surprisingly announced his retirement on Thursday, one of his former bosses wanted to be sure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Disco Queens for Halloween
description: And galas for the American Ballet Theater and the Studio Museum in Harlem.
content: Glam disco was the theme at the 25th Hulaween party, held on Oct. 30 at Cipriani South Street to benefit the New York Restoration Project, the nonprofit started by Bette Midler to protect green spaces. The American Ballet Theater honored Jenna Segal at its fall gala on Oct. 26; the performance was followed by a dinner. And the Studio Museum in Harlem held a black-tie benefit at the Glass House on Oct. 25 with plenty of dancing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: How Frequent Flier Programs Are Changing in a Changed World
description: In an era of climate change and virus concerns, it’s a challenging time to keep fliers loyal. Here is how U.S. airlines are trying to keep up.
content: The pandemic made an oxymoron of the term “frequent flier,” as the number of airline passengers plummeted in the early days of the lockdown. Leisure travel has recovered somewhat, but the more lucrative business travel market is still way off, with recovery not expected until 2023 and perhaps not even then.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Change your clocks, contemplate your dreams.
content: Welcome. It’s that time again, the end of daylight saving. Set your clocks back before you go to sleep on Saturday. Where I live, it’ll be darker earlier for the next several months. The beginning of the frigid season: seven weeks until Christmas, four-and-a-half months until spring. Get comfortable. Get cozy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Vienna will start to vaccinate young children without E.U. approval.
description: Pediatricians in the Austrian capital will authorize the off-label use of the BioNTech-Pfizer vaccine for children starting next Friday.
content: The city of Vienna will help vaccinate children as young as 5 against Covid, without official approval from the E.U., officials announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: A Missed Connection at Whole Foods
description: And: Love and marriage after 80.
content: You never know if a stroll down the produce aisle could lead to a love connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz and Emily Cochrane
title: 2,000 Pages and Pronto! Budget Scorekeepers Are Under Pressure
description: Lawmakers want detailed estimates on the effects of the big Democratic bill, but that can take longer than they think, slowing the process.
content: When Democratic House moderates raised their latest objection to voting on the party’s social spending and climate bill on Friday, they said they first needed a “score” from the Congressional Budget Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marion Renault
title: This Eagle Is Very, Very Lost
description: Bird-watchers have been tracking a Steller’s sea eagle. They’re usually found in Asia, but this one turned up in Eastern Canada and may have flown as far as South Texas.
content: Geographically speaking, it would be almost impossible for this bird to get any more lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: The defense cites a citizen’s arrest law that has been largely repealed.
description: A lawyer for Travis McMichael is the first on the defense side to to argue that when Ahmaud Arbery was killed, his client was trying to make a citizen’s arrest permitted under state law.
content: Robert Rubin, a lawyer for Travis McMichael, became the first defense lawyer for any of the three men accused of murdering Ahmaud Arbery to argue that his client was trying to make a citizen’s arrest permitted under state law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: At Colin Powell’s Funeral, Washington Unites to Pay Tribute
description: Republicans and Democrats, including President Biden and two of his predecessors, were at the Washington National Cathedral to honor the former secretary of state.
content: The funeral for Colin L. Powell, former secretary of state, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and national security adviser, brought out a Washington that barely exists anymore: Republicans and Democrats, including President Biden and two of his predecessors, uniformed military and diplomats, and people on all sides of the Iraq war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: An Adventure in the Conventional
description: Jessica Rosenblum was initially more interested in redecorating Steve Young’s loft apartment than she was in him.
content: On their first date, at a New York restaurant in late February 2020, Jessica Rosenblum told Steve Young that he looked like a lot more fun in his photo, which was provided by an acquaintance who had set them up. He laughed, delighted by her “cutting” sense of humor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Why We Have to Wave the ‘Bloody Shirt’ of Jan. 6
description: Somehow, we imagine that the politics of the past was more civil, more genteel, more rational. But it wasn’t.
content: Policy is rational. Politics is not. It takes a story to move voters, an emotional connection that tells them something about themselves and the world in which they live or, alternately, the world in which they would like to live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons
title: Here are the charges that the defendants face.
description: Taken together, the charges provide a number of different ways that the defendants, Gregory McMichael, Travis McMichael and William Bryan, could wind up facing life in prison if they are convicted.
content: The indictment handed up by the grand jury in Glynn County lists nine criminal counts against each of the three defendants in the killing of Ahmaud Arbery. For each count, they are charged individually and as “parties concerned in the commission of a crime.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: The Moose Came Marching In, and Stole the Hearts of Canadians
description: In a prairie city, a young moose on the loose crashed into a children’s classroom, sparking a mix of delight and concern on social media.
content: She was a young moose, not even 2 years old, still getting used to her surroundings, when she took a wrong turn on Thursday and crashed through the window of an elementary school classroom in Saskatoon, in Canada’s central prairie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Former U.S.C. Official Pleads Guilty in College Admissions Scandal
description: Donna Heinel admitted to being part of a sweeping scheme that helped fake athletic recruits get into top universities, in exchange for bribes.
content: A former University of Southern California athletic administrator pleaded guilty to being part of a sweeping scheme to get students admitted to prestigious universities as fake athletic recruits, in exchange for bribes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: A Nuclear-Powered Shower? Russia Tests a Climate Innovation.
description: A remote Siberian town now has its own miniature nuclear plant as a Russian state company tests a new model for residential heating. Some see it as a tool to minimize climate change.
content: PEVEK, Russia — The water was hot, steamy and plentiful, and Pavel Rozhkov let it flow over his body, enjoying a shower that is not for the squeamish: On his bare skin, he was feeling the heat produced by an atomic reaction, pumped directly from a nuclear reactor into his home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The Fastest Man Ever to Run the New York City Marathon Has Arrived
description: In 2019, Kenenisa Bekele came within two seconds of breaking Eliud Kipchoge’s world record. At 39, the Ethiopian champion has come to New York to prove he can still win anywhere.
content: Kenenisa Bekele, arguably the greatest distance runner ever, is not really supposed to be here. In New York. Running another marathon, just six weeks after the last one. Believing he is on the cusp of proving to the world that he is the fastest marathoner alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: ‘The Visitor’ Lags Behind the Times
description: The new musical, based on the 2008 film and delayed by the pandemic, debuts at the Public Theater. But its story of a white professor helping immigrants feels out of step with the moment.
content: What comes to mind when you think about immigration, ICE and deportation? I’m willing to bet more than a few George Washingtons that it’s not “musical.” Perhaps it is doable to respect the politics around these issues and the immigrants trying to build a life in the United States in this format, but it’s tough. Which is why the new musical “The Visitor” feels so obtuse and helplessly dated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Canelo Álvarez Hopes to Unify the Belts at 168 Pounds
description: It’s difficult to be an undisputed champion in boxing. Álvarez feels he can burnish his legacy by taking all the major belts at 168 pounds.
content: LAS VEGAS — Saúl Álvarez and Caleb Plant punctuated their late-September news conference in Beverly Hills the way prizefighters often do — by squaring off for a stare-down, nose to nose, each promising to beat the other down when they finally met for the undisputed super-middleweight title. That bout is scheduled for Saturday night at the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Smithsonian Moves Toward Returning Benin Bronzes
description: The institution’s National Museum of African Art says it has removed the artworks from display. It is the latest museum to begin a process that could lead to the return of the works to Nigeria.
content: The head of the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of African Art said Friday that museum officials have removed its Benin Bronzes from display and plan to begin the process of potentially repatriating the priceless West African artifacts that were looted by the British Army more than a century ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, as always, present us with a puzzle to remember.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is from a 2018 book by Melissa Dahl called “Cringeworthy: A Theory of Awkwardness,” which explores putting your foot in your mouth as a fundamental human experience. The passage concerns memories, both fond and embarrassing, forged at particular moments in one’s life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘First Principles’ and ‘The Searcher’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: COLLECTED STORIES, by Shirley Hazzard. Edited by Brigitta Olubas. Foreword by Zoë Heller. (Picador, 368 pp., $18.) Gathered into a single “important and elegant volume,” as the Times critic Dwight Garner called it, the National Book Award-winning Australian American writer’s short stories from the 1960s (before she turned to novels) show “a mature talent,” dispensing “intelligence and irony as if each were fresh herbs in a reticule she kept tied to the belt of her dress.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: The fatal encounter at the center of the Arbery murder trial was captured on cellphone video.
description: The final minutes of Ahmaud Arbery’s life were captured in a cellphone video taken by one of three men now accused of killing him last year while he was on a jog in a suburban Brunswick, Ga., neighborhood.

author: By Lauren Kelley
title: Tell Us Your Abortion Story
description: We want to hear about your experience in your own voice.
content: Earlier this fall, during a House Oversight Committee hearing on the multipronged threat to American reproductive rights, several members of Congress shared their stories of having had abortions. The testimonies, from Representatives Cori Bush of Missouri, Pramila Jayapal of Washington and Barbara Lee of California, were all deeply moving in their own way. But one moment from that day stood out to me the most. “Today I share for the first time publicly a very difficult personal story, hoping that it will help destigmatize accessing abortion care,” said Ms. Lee. “I’m sharing my story even though I truly believe it is personal, and really nobody’s business.”

title: Another Landmark Lost, This Time on Astor Row in Harlem

title: Kyrsten Sinema and the Politics of a Sleeveless Silhouette
description: Michelle Obama, Kyrsten Sinema and the right to bare arms.
content: Last week, I argued that it was useful to think about the clothes Kyrsten Sinema wears, because her presentation is part of her political power. I also invited readers to think along with me. Many of you wrote me to say that the very idea of talking about what a woman is wearing gives you, for lack of a better term, the heebie-jeebies. Some of you worry that this line of inquiry devalues Sinema’s credentials and office; others worry that talking about presentation is tacitly sexist because it opens the door to critiquing women for something that their male counterparts can take for granted.
